newsitem.title: CHINA: HK finance boss says labour rights harmful.
newsitem.headline: HK finance boss says labour rights harmful.

text.p: Hong Kong Financial Secretary Donald Tsang said on Wednesday that trade union rights enacted in the last days of British rule would undermine Hong Kong's economic competitiveness.

Tsang was speaking as debate raged in Hong Kong over the government's attempt to ram through a bill suspending labour laws that allow unions collective bargaining and the right to use funds for political activities.
He told reporters as the legislature convened on Wednesday that the labour laws could deter foreign investors and hit Hong Kong's credit ratings.
"From the point of view of the investor, certainly, it is a disincentive that we have in our labour legislation provisions such as collective bargaining," Tsang said.
"From the international credit rating agency's point of view, this is something we have to look at very carefully. It may affect Hong Kong's competitiveness," Tsang said.

Only days before Hong Kong became part of China on July 1, the old legislature passed bills beefing up trade union powers. But the post-colonial government is asking the new legislature to suspend the laws pending a review.
Tsang said the government wanted time, possibly two months, to analyse the labour laws, and would then come back to the legislature with its findings.
